ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Overview of blockchain technology and applications
I learned a lot about blockchains and consensus protocols.
blockchain concepts
Broad overview of cryptocurrencies.

It is a good course. I learn about blockchains and cryptocurrencies systematically. I can tell the professor has spent much effort on preparing for the course materials and the professor has a deep understanding of the topic.
Blockchain Knowledge
You learn a thorough view of blockchain and cryptocurrencies, starting with blockchain infrastructure (low-level) to smart contracts (high-level).
Introduction to consensus and current blockchains

We learned about various cryptocurrencies (Blockchain, Ethereum), underlying protocols (POW, POS), data structures (hashes, merkle trees), smart contracts, defi lending, and more. We gained perspectives from various guest in the crypto space via guest lectures, and we learned Solidity by coding two contracts as class projects.
Understanding of correctness of Nakamoto consensus, how Proof of Stake works, what smart contracts are and how to write them

I learned a lot from the very fundamental theories of blockchain to the applications, such as asychronous protocols and defis. We also had wonderful guest speakers to talk about their real world experience in this field.
Coding in Solidity
Basic understanding of Blockchain technology

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Good primer for blockchain technologies

Weaknesses: Course covers material at superficial depth and is not very engaging. Course staff other than Prof. Fisch is extremely unknowledgable, so the only person who you can ask questions to is the professor.
A lot of interesting content, and the problem sets were quite good.
interesting concepts but a lot of material
Strength: super cool speakers brought in from leading companies. Weakness: lectures were sporadic.

The strengths is the course itself is really interesting and we can learn the world of blockchains from it, starting from basic to advance.
One weakness may be the organization of the timeline. Finally, we are a little fall behind our original schedule and thus we did not go deep into the topic of zero knowledge proof, which is the most interesting part in my own opinion.
It should be recorded.
Better slides / lectures, recorded lectures

The course gives a great overview of the major topics in the crypto space (how cryptocurrencies work, how to code Ethereum contracts, etc.) and helps put a lot of the different areas of research related to crypto into perspective. The psets can feel highly technical at times, and I would have liked a more structured teaching approach (high level before low level) so we could become familiar with the necessary vocabulary in a topic before diving into say the mathematical weeds. The psets do feel quite challenging as they also grapple with topics at a very technical level, so I found using OH often. That being said, I found the Solidity projects to be more rewarding than challenging.

The content is interesting and I enjoyed the guest lectures. The psets/projects also effectively complement the information given during lectures. The workload of the class could be less backloaded - having a pset, project, final and report (for grad students) within the last few weeks of the semester is overwhelming and, in my opinion, unnecessary. I also found the final very difficult and could not finish it within the 3-hour timeslot.
It actually requires a lot of prerequites to fully understand the course materials.

Ben is very smart, but sometimes we lose the forest for the trees. There is too much specific info that we don't need to know and are never tested on, and then it is very confusing since we have some specific info that we need to know. This course can be streamlined and made more conscise.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Likely not, just because of how superficially the content is covered.
Yes, the content was interesting and Prof Fisch is a good lecturer. There were also several guest lectures, which I enjoyed as well.
yes

Absolutely if you want to get a full understanding of how blockchain works. The course starts at the consensus layer and builds all the way up to the application layer. It explores various of topics ranging from Solidity programming to the economics of DeFi.
Yes. Very interesting material that seems very relevant today and for future developments.
Yes. It is a good starting point for exploring the world of blockchains.
Great Professor

This course is only for those who are genuinely curious about the subject - this course feels like it stuffed too many concepts into a single semester, starting from the foundations of blockchain all the way to the cutting edge.
Not really, course needs refinement
Yes, but the psets require lots of technical analysis so would only recommend only if you have a comfortable math background (don't expect to be coding for psets, only the projects).
Yes, it covers a lot of topics. Anyone interested in blockchain should take it.
yes, only if you LOVE crypto. If you don't care, this is not an elective for you.
